Nazi Policies Toward Jews and Minorities

abstract.p: Istvan B Gereben letter, commenting on August 14 article on compensation for Gypsies who were victims of Nazis, says issue goes beyond compensation for injustices of past

block.p: ''Gypsies and the Holocaust'' (editorial, Aug. 14) points out that the Gypsies of Eastern Europe have not received adequate compensation for their suffering in World War II. The issue, however, goes beyond compensation for the injustices of the past.

''Gypsies and the Holocaust'' (editorial, Aug. 14) points out that the Gypsies of Eastern Europe have not received adequate compensation for their suffering in World War II. The issue, however, goes beyond compensation for the injustices of the past.
Today, too, Gypsies face general insensitivity and discrimination, as well as serious problems in housing, employment, education and medical treatment in both Eastern and Western Europe.

Unfortunately, Europe does not have leaders with the moral character, political authority and commitment to human rights of Konrad Adenauer, the former West German chancellor, or his sense of responsibility to stand up for the well-being of the neglected and the disenfranchised of the Continent.
Until such a leader appears, the struggle of the Gypsies will not only be difficult but possibly fruitless as well.
ISTVAN B. GEREBEN Rockwood, Pa., Aug. 14, 2000
